radiology:
Note ID: 10040626-RR-9
Modality: CT
Region: Abdomen
Exam Name: CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST
Report: EXAMINATION:
CT ABD AND PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:

TECHNIQUE:
MDCT images were obtained from the lung bases to the pubic
symphysis after administration of 130cc intravenous contrast.  Axial images
were interpreted in conjunction with coronal and sagittal reformats.

DLP:
404 mGy-cm
CTDIvol:  8 mGy

FINDINGS:


CHEST:
The visualized lung bases are clear.  There is no pleural or pericardial
effusion.

ABDOMEN:
The liver and gallbladder are normal.  The portal and hepatic veins are
patent. The pancreas and spleen are unremarkable.  The adrenal glands are
normal bilaterally.  The kidneys enhance symmetrically with no hydronephrosis.

The stomach and small bowel are normal in caliber. Within the right lower
quadrant, there is a dilated, hyperdense structure rising from the base of the
cecum, which measures up to 9 mm, likely representing the appendix
demonstrating mucosal hyperenhancment with respect to adjacent bowel.  What is
most striking is hyperenhancement and wall thickening rather than fluid
content.  Inflammatory changes are noted at the base of the cecum, and
adjacent to the whole wall of the appendix, and probably particularly at the
tip, which has an indistinct appearance.

Within the mesentery adjacent to the ascending colon, there are two strikingly
enlarged and briskly enhancing lymph nodes measuring 1.4 and 1.8 cm, the
former with low-density material centrally, and both demonstrate surrounding
inflammatory changes, including marked fat stranding about the node with
suspected necrotic or suppurative changes.

The ascending, transverse, and descending colon are unremarkable. There is no
mesenteric free air.

PELVIS:
The urinary bladder, and adnexa are unremarkable. The uterus contains
an intrauterine device, and standard position. Small amount of simple free
fluid is seen in the pelvis, likely physiologic.

VESSELS:
The aorta is normal in caliber and its major branches are patent.

OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:
No focal lytic or sclerotic lesion concerning for
malignancy.

NOTIFICATION:
Findings were discussed with Dr. ___ by Dr. ___
telephone at 23:52 on ___.

present_illness: The patient is a ___ year old male with medical history for chronic lower back pain who now presents with complaint of right lower quadrant/flank abdominal pain since this morning.  According to the patient, he was feeling well until yesterday afternoon, when he developed acute-onset of back pain. He does have a history of chronic lower back pain with multiple surgical interventions, however he states that the quality of the pain during this episode was different than his usual pain. These symptoms continued through-out the night, and this morning he noted that the discomfort had localized to the right lower quadrant/flank instead. At this time he also began experiencing some mild nausea, but no emesis. Due to the unusual and non-resolving nature of his symptoms, he presented to the ED for further evaluation.  He denies any fever or chills, has had normal bowel movements, and normal appetite (indeed, the patient reports feeling quite hungry). No recent sick contacts. No other associated systemic symptoms.     Past Medical History: Asthma, HT,neuropathy in bilateral legs and arm for multiple  years, GERD,   Recent weight loss>    Social History: ___ Family History: Non-contributory
physical_examination: Admission   Vitals: Temp: 98 HR: 112  Resp: 16  O2Sat: 97% General: No acute distress; alert and fully oriented Cardiac: Regular rate and rhythm; normal S1 and S2 Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally Abdomen: Soft, non-distended, acutely tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant; mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant; (+) rebound; (-) gaurding; (+) Rovsing/(+)Psoas signs Extremities: Warm and well-perfused

radiology:
Note ID: 10070247-RR-22
Modality: CT
Region: Abdomen
Exam Name: CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST
Report: TECHNIQUE:
MDCT images were obtained of the abdomen and pelvis after the
administration of intravenous contrast.  Reformatted coronal and sagittal
images were reviewed.

FINDINGS:


CT ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST:
The bases of the lungs are clear.  Within the
liver, there are calcifications within the left hepatic lobe which are
oriented in a linear configuration and possibly represent prior trauma or
infection.   No suspicious focal lesions are identified within the liver.  The
portal vein is patent.  The gallbladder is unremarkable.  There is no intra or
extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation.  The pancreas, bilateral adrenal
glands, spleen and bilateral kidneys are normal in appearance.  The stomach,
duodenum and small bowel are also normal in appearance with no evidence of
wall thickening or obstruction.

Within the right lower quadrant, there is an enlarged and fluid-filled
appendix with apparent fecal material within the base of the appendix,
measuring up to 2.1 cm in greatest diameter at the base (2:49).  Surrounding
inflammatory fat stranding is also present.  There is no evidence of
extraluminal air or drainable fluid collection.  Multiple small reactive lymph
nodes are also present within the right lower quadrant.  The remaining large
bowel is unremarkable with no evidence of wall thickening or obstruction. 
There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymph node enlargement.  The
intra-abdominal vasculature demonstrates a normal caliber aorta throughout and
a widely patent celiac axis, superior mesenteric and inferior mesenteric
artery.  Two right renal arteries are present.  There is relative atrophy of
the left rectus abdominis muscle, likely secondary to prior surgery with
multiple left-sided abdominal wall clips in place.

CT PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:
The terminal ureters are unremarkable.  The
bladder wall is slightly thickened, possibly due to incomplete distention. 
The rectum and sigmoid are unremarkable.  There is no pelvic sidewall or
inguinal lymphadenopathy.  A small fat-containing left inguinal hernia is
present.  There is no pelvic free fluid.

OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:
There is evidence of prior spinal fusion at the L4-L5
level with apparent donor graft site within the right iliac bone.  No
suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesion is present.   There has been interval
removal of orthopedic hardware from the lumbar spine.

Patient denies fever, chills but reports some nausea and dry heaving.   He has had decreased appetite but denies diarrhea and hematochezia.   He is passing flatus and his last bowel movement was yesterday afternoon.  He reports that his pain has improved after  receiving morphine. radiology:
Note ID: 10073256-RR-10
Modality: Ultrasound
Region: Venous
Exam Name: UNILAT UP EXT VEINS US LEFT
Report: LEFT UPPER EXTREMITY ULTRASOUND:
Gray-scale, color, and Doppler ultrasound
were used to evaluate the left internal jugular, subclavian, axillary,
basilic, brachial and cephalic veins.  Vessels in the forearm are also
evaluated.  The cephalic vein contains expansile echogenic material, extending
from the forearm to the mid upper arm, compatible with occlusive thrombus. 
More proximally in the upper arm, cephalic vein is compressible and
demonstrates flow.  Clot does not extend to the deep system.

Deep veins of the left upper extremity, including the basilic, brachial,
axillary and subclavian veins are compressible (where applicable) with normal
waveforms.

Note ID: 10073256-RR-11
Modality: Ultrasound
Region: Venous
Exam Name: UNILAT UP EXT VEINS US RIGHT
Report: RIGHT UPPER EXTREMITY VENOUS ULTRASOUND.:


FINDINGS:
Grayscale and color sonograms of bilateral subclavian and
right-sided internal jugular, cephalic, axillary, basilic, and brachial veins
were evaluated.  There is unchanged appearance of the waveforms in the
subclavian veins.  Remaining vessels demonstrated normal flow,
compressibility, and augmentation.

Note ID: 10073256-RR-7
Modality: CT
Region: Abdomen
Exam Name: CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST
Report: EXAM:
Abdomen and pelvis CT.

TECHNIQUE:
This is an interpretation of images acquired at an outside
institution, for second opinion reading.  Data was acquired from the abdomen
and pelvis after the administration of intravenous contrast.  Images were
displayed in the axial and coronal planes.  Sagittal reformats were not
included with the outside hospital images as is protocol at ___.

FINDINGS:
There is bilateral dependent atelectasis in the lung bases.  The
heart is grossly normal.

ABDOMEN WITH CONTRAST:
There are two hypodensities within the liver
parenchyma, the more superior in segment VIII (2:14) measures 5 x 8 mm and is
too small to fully characterize.  There is a second lobulated hypodensity
within segment IVb (2:33), which measures 14 x 14 mm, not fully characterized
on this single phase study, but may represent a cyst.  However, consider
ultrasound if there is history of malignancy for further evaluation.
Comparison with prior CT studies would be helpful.  The gallbladder is normal.
The pancreas, spleen, and adrenal glands are normal.  The kidneys enhance
symmetrically.  There is a 32 x 27 mm cyst in the upper pole of the right
kidney.  No bowel obstruction is seen.  There is no ascites.  There is no free
abdominal air.

PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:
There is a hyperemic dilated appendix with a maximum
diameter of 16 mm (2:61).  There is a proximal appendicolith (2:58) and
adjacent cecal wall thickening.  There is surrounding mesenteric stranding and
a small amount of adjacent free fluid without a well-defined rim (2:62).  No
drainable fluid collection or extraluminal gas is seen.

High density material in the prostate which are most likely brachytherapy
seeds.  The bladder and rectum are normal.  There is no pelvic
lymphadenopathy.

BONE WINDOWS:
There are no fractures, lytic or sclerotic lesions.

Note ID: 10073256-RR-8
Modality: Radiograph
Region: Chest
Exam Name: CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
Report: EXAM:
Chest AP upright portable view.

FINDINGS:
Single AP upright portable view of the chest was obtained.  There
are relatively low lung volumes.  Patchy left base opacity is seen which could
relate to atelectasis although consolidation from pneumonia or aspiration is
not excluded.  There is also patchy right base opacity and minimal streaky
medial right upper lobe opacity, both of which could be due to atelectasis,
aspiration or infection.  No pneumothorax is seen.  There is no evidence of
large pleural effusion.  The aorta is calcified and tortuous.  The cardiac
silhouette is not enlarged.

Note ID: 10073256-RR-9
Modality: Radiograph
Region: Chest
Exam Name: CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
Report: FINDINGS:
Portable semi-upright AP radiograph of the chest is submitted for
review.  Nasogastric tube is seen with distal tip in the proximal stomach and
proximal side port located at or slightly above the gastroesophageal junction.
It should be advanced for optimal positioning.  Relatively low lung volumes
are again noted.  

Patchy streak-like opacities are noted within the right and left bases as well
as right upper lobe and likely represent atelectasis.  There has been interval
development of bilateral pleural effusions along with interstitial opacities,
more prominent on the right than the left, consistent with pulmonary edema. 
The cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal in appearance.  There is no
pneumothorax.

radiology:
Note ID: 10080679-RR-12
Modality: Ultrasound
Region: Abdomen
Exam Name: US ABD LIMIT, SINGLE ORGAN
Report: FINDINGS:
Sonographic evaluation of the right lower abdominal quadrant in the
region of the patient's pain demonstrates a noncompressible blind-ending
tubular structure arising from the expected location of the cecum, likely the
appendix.  This structure measures up to 1.3 cm in caliber and contains
heterogeneous debris.  There is no significant surrounding hyperemia.  No
periappendiceal fluid collection is identified.

radiology:
Note ID: 10085111-RR-12
Modality: CT
Region: Abdomen
Exam Name: CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST
Report: TECHNIQUE:
MDCT images were obtained from the lung bases to the pubic
symphysis after administration of 150 cc of IV Omnipaque contrast.  Axial
images were interpreted in conjunction with coronal and sagittal reformats.

FINDINGS:
The visualized heart is normal. Lung bases are clear.  No pericardial or
pleural effusion.

ABDOMEN:
The liver is normal without focal or diffuse abnormality. The gallbladder,
intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts, pancreas, and bilateral adrenal glands
are normal.  The spleen is top normal size, 13.0 cm.  The kidneys enhance
symmetrically and excrete contrast promptly.  The ureters are normal in course
and caliber.

The stomach is normal.  The small and large bowel enhance homogeneously and
have a normal course and calibur.  

The appendix is dilated to 9 mm, is fluid filled, and has periappendiceal
stranding.  No extraluminal gas or periappendiceal collection.  

No retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy.  The portal and
intra-abdominal systemic vasculature are normal.  The left renal vein is
retroaortic.  No abdominal wall hernia, pneumoperitoneum, or free abdominal
fluid.

PELVIS:
The bladder and terminal ureters are normal.  The prostate gland is
unremarkable.  2.2 cm hypodense structure in the right inguinal canal (2: 97)
extending into the right pelvis is compatible with the right testis.  A
bilobed hypodense structure anterior to the left external iliac vessels (2:83)
extending into the left inguinal canal is compatible with undescended
testicles.  No pelvic side-wall or inguinal lymphadenopathy. No free pelvic
fluid or inguinal hernia.

OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:
No focal lytic or sclerotic lesion concerning for
malignancy.
